member.name: M:Humanizer.ByteSize.ToString
member.summary: Converts the value of the current ByteSize object to a string. The metric prefix symbol (bit, byte, kilo, mega, giga, tera) used is the largest metric prefix such that the corresponding value is greater than or equal to one.

member.name: M:Humanizer.ByteSize.ToFullWords(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Converts the value of the current ByteSize object to a string with full words. The metric prefix symbol (bit, byte, kilo, mega, giga, tera) used is the largest metric prefix such that the corresponding value is greater than or equal to one.

member.name: T:Humanizer.CasingExtensions
member.summary: ApplyCase method to allow changing the case of a sentence easily

member.name: M:Humanizer.CasingExtensions.ApplyCase(System.String,Humanizer.LetterCasing)
member.summary: Applies the specified letter casing transformation to the input string.
member.param: The string to transform. Must not be null.
The desired letter casing style to apply to the input string.
member.returns: A new string with the specified casing applied. - : Each word is capitalized (e.g., "Some String") - : All letters are lowercase (e.g., "some string") - : All letters are uppercase (e.g., "SOME STRING") - : First letter capitalized, rest lowercase (e.g., "Some string")
member.exception: Thrown when an invalid value is provided.

example.code: "some string".ApplyCase(LetterCasing.Title) => "Some String" "SOME STRING".ApplyCase(LetterCasing.LowerCase) => "some string" "some string".ApplyCase(LetterCasing.AllCaps) => "SOME STRING" "some string".ApplyCase(LetterCasing.Sentence) => "Some string"

member.name: T:Humanizer.CollectionHumanizeExtensions
member.summary: Humanizes an IEnumerable into a human readable list

member.name: M:Humanizer.CollectionHumanizeExtensions.Humanize``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Transforms a collection into a human-readable string representation by calling on each element and combining them with the default separator for the current culture (typically ", " with "and" before the last item).
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the collection.
member.param: The collection to be humanized. Must not be null.
member.returns: A formatted string representation of the collection elements separated by culture-specific separators. For English, this typically produces: "item1, item2 and item3".
member.exception: Thrown when is null.

example.code: new[] { 1, 2, 3 }.Humanize() => "1, 2 and 3" new[] { "Alice", "Bob", "Charlie" }.Humanize() => "Alice, Bob and Charlie" new[] { "single" }.Humanize() => "single" new string[] { }.Humanize() => ""

member.name: M:Humanizer.CollectionHumanizeExtensions.Humanize``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.String})
member.summary: Transforms a collection into a human-readable string representation using a custom formatter function for each element, combined with the default separator for the current culture.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the collection.
member.param: The collection to be humanized. Must not be null.
A function that converts each element of type to a string representation. Must not be null.
member.returns: A formatted string representation of the collection elements, where each element is formatted using and separated by culture-specific separators.
member.exception: Thrown when or is null.

member.name: M:Humanizer.CollectionHumanizeExtensions.Humanize``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Object})
member.summary: Transforms a collection into a human-readable string representation using a custom formatter function that returns an object for each element (which will be converted to string), combined with the default separator for the current culture.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the collection.
member.param: The collection to be humanized. Must not be null.
A function that converts each element of type to an object that will be converted to its string representation. Must not be null.
member.returns: A formatted string representation of the collection elements, where each element is formatted using and separated by culture-specific separators.
member.exception: Thrown when or is null.

example.code: var numbers = new[] { 1, 2, 3 }; numbers.Humanize(n => n * 2) => "2, 4 and 6"

member.name: M:Humanizer.CollectionHumanizeExtensions.Humanize``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.String)
member.summary: Transforms a collection into a string representation by calling on each element and combining them with the specified separator.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the collection.
member.param: The collection to be humanized. Must not be null.
The string to use as a separator between elements.
member.returns: A string representation of the collection elements separated by the specified separator.
member.exception: Thrown when is null.

member.name: M:Humanizer.CollectionHumanizeExtensions.Humanize``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.String},System.String)
member.summary: Transforms a collection into a string representation using a custom formatter function for each element, combined with the specified separator.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the collection.
member.param: The collection to be humanized. Must not be null.
A function that converts each element of type to a string representation. Must not be null.
The string to use as a separator between formatted elements.
member.returns: A string representation of the collection elements, where each element is formatted using and separated by the specified separator.
member.exception: Thrown when or is null.

example.code: var people = new[] { new Person { Name = "Alice" }, new Person { Name = "Bob" } }; people.Humanize(p => p.Name, " | ") => "Alice | Bob"

member.name: P:Humanizer.Configurator.DateTimeHumanizeStrategy
member.summary: The strategy to be used for DateTime.Humanize
member.remarks: This property should be set only once during application startup before any humanization operations occur. For thread-safety, use volatile reads or appropriate synchronization when accessing this property in multi-threaded scenarios. In production applications, avoid changing this value after the application has started serving requests.

member.name: T:Humanizer.DateToOrdinalWordsExtensions
member.summary: Humanizes DateTime into human readable sentence

member.name: M:Humanizer.DateToOrdinalWordsExtensions.ToOrdinalWords(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Converts a to its ordinal words representation (e.g., "1st of January, 2023").
member.param: The date to be converted to ordinal words.
member.returns: A string containing the date expressed in ordinal words format, culture-specific. For English: "1st of January, 2023", "22nd of December, 2020", etc.
member.remarks: The format and style of ordinal words depends on the current culture. Uses the configured date-to-ordinal-words converter for conversion.

example.code: new DateTime(2023, 1, 1).ToOrdinalWords() => "1st of January, 2023" (in en-US culture) new DateTime(2020, 12, 22).ToOrdinalWords() => "22nd of December, 2020" (in en-US culture)

member.name: M:Humanizer.DateToOrdinalWordsExtensions.ToOrdinalWords(System.DateTime,Humanizer.GrammaticalCase)
member.summary: Converts a to its ordinal words representation using the specified grammatical case.
member.param: The date to be converted to ordinal words.
The grammatical case to use for the output words (e.g., Nominative, Genitive, etc.). This is particularly important for languages with case systems like Russian, Polish, etc.
member.returns: A string containing the date expressed in ordinal words format in the specified grammatical case.
member.remarks: The grammatical case parameter is primarily used by languages that have case systems. For languages without grammatical cases (like English), this parameter has no effect.

member.name: T:Humanizer.EnumDehumanizeExtensions
member.summary: Contains extension methods for dehumanizing Enum string values.

member.name: M:Humanizer.EnumDehumanizeExtensions.DehumanizeTo``1(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a humanized string back to its original enum value by matching it against enum member names and their humanized representations (including values).
member.typeparam: The enum type to convert to. Must be a struct and implement .
member.param: The humanized string to be converted back to an enum value. Must not be null.
member.returns: The enum value that matches the input string.
member.exception: Thrown when is not an enum type.
Thrown when no enum member matches the input string (including checking member names, humanized names, and description attributes).
member.remarks: The method attempts to match the input string against: 1. The exact enum member name 2. The humanized version of the enum member name 3. Any value on the enum member Matching is case-sensitive.

example.code: enum UserType { AnonymousUser, RegisteredUser } "Anonymous user".DehumanizeTo<UserType>() => UserType.AnonymousUser "Registered user".DehumanizeTo<UserType>() => UserType.RegisteredUser "AnonymousUser".DehumanizeTo<UserType>() => UserType.AnonymousUser

member.name: M:Humanizer.EnumDehumanizeExtensions.DehumanizeTo``1(System.String,Humanizer.OnNoMatch)
member.summary: Converts a humanized string back to its original enum value with configurable behavior when no match is found.
member.typeparam: The enum type to convert to. Must be a struct and implement .
member.param: The humanized string to be converted back to an enum value. Must not be null.
Specifies what to do when no matching enum member is found. Default is .
member.returns: The enum value that matches the input string, or null if no match is found and is set to .
member.exception: Thrown when is not an enum type.
Thrown when no enum member matches the input string and is set to .
member.remarks: This overload provides more control over error handling compared to the parameterless version.

example.code: enum UserType { AnonymousUser, RegisteredUser } "Anonymous user".DehumanizeTo<UserType>() => UserType.AnonymousUser "Invalid".DehumanizeTo<UserType>(OnNoMatch.ReturnsNull) => null "Invalid".DehumanizeTo<UserType>(OnNoMatch.ThrowsException) => throws NoMatchFoundException

member.name: M:Humanizer.EnumDehumanizeExtensions.DehumanizeTo(System.String,System.Type,Humanizer.OnNoMatch)
member.summary: Converts a humanized string back to its original enum value using runtime type information. This is a non-generic overload that accepts the target enum type as a parameter.
member.param: The humanized string to be converted back to an enum value. Must not be null.
The of the target enum. Must be an enum type.
Specifies what to do when no matching enum member is found. Default is .
member.returns: The enum value (as ) that matches the input string.
member.exception: Thrown when no enum member matches the input string and is set to .
Thrown when is not an enum type.
member.remarks: This method uses reflection and is less type-safe than the generic overload. Use the generic method when the target enum type is known at compile time.

example.code: enum UserType { AnonymousUser, RegisteredUser } "Anonymous user".DehumanizeTo(typeof(UserType)) => UserType.AnonymousUser (as Enum)

member.name: T:Humanizer.EnumHumanizeExtensions
member.summary: Contains extension methods for humanizing Enums

member.name: M:Humanizer.EnumHumanizeExtensions.Humanize``1(``0)
member.summary: Converts an enum value to a human-readable string by intelligently formatting the enum member name and respecting any applied to the member.
member.typeparam: The enum type. Must be a struct and implement .
member.param: The enum value to be humanized.
member.returns: A human-readable string representation of the enum value. If the enum has the and multiple flags are set, returns a humanized, comma-separated list of the flag values. If a is present on the enum member, its value is returned. Otherwise, the enum member name is humanized (e.g., "AnonymousUser" becomes "Anonymous user").
member.remarks: For flags enums, only non-zero flags are included in the output, and each flag is humanized individually. The humanization process converts PascalCase to space-separated text with appropriate capitalization.

member.name: M:Humanizer.EnumHumanizeExtensions.Humanize``1(``0,Humanizer.LetterCasing)
member.summary: Converts an enum value to a human-readable string with the specified letter casing applied. Respects any applied to the enum member.
member.typeparam: The enum type. Must be a struct and implement .
member.param: The enum value to be humanized.
The desired letter casing to apply to the humanized enum value.
member.returns: A human-readable string representation of the enum value with the specified casing applied. If a is present, its value is used and then cased.
member.remarks: This is a convenience method that combines with .

example.code: enum UserType { AnonymousUser, RegisteredUser } UserType.AnonymousUser.Humanize(LetterCasing.AllCaps) => "ANONYMOUS USER" UserType.AnonymousUser.Humanize(LetterCasing.Title) => "Anonymous User" UserType.AnonymousUser.Humanize(LetterCasing.LowerCase) => "anonymous user"

member.name: T:Humanizer.Vocabularies
member.summary: Container for registered Vocabularies. At present, only a single vocabulary is supported: Default.

member.name: P:Humanizer.Vocabularies.Default
member.summary: The default vocabulary used for singular/plural irregularities. Rules can be added to this vocabulary and will be picked up by called to Singularize() and Pluralize(). At this time, multiple vocabularies and removing existing rules are not supported.

member.name: T:Humanizer.Vocabulary
member.summary: A container for exceptions to simple pluralization/singularization rules. Vocabularies.Default contains an extensive list of rules for US English. At this time, multiple vocabularies and removing existing rules are not supported.

member.name: M:Humanizer.Vocabulary.AddIrregular(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a word to the vocabulary which cannot easily be pluralized/singularized by RegEx, e.g. "person" and "people".
member.param: The singular form of the irregular word, e.g. "person".
The plural form of the irregular word, e.g. "people".
True to match these words on their own as well as at the end of longer words. False, otherwise.

member.name: M:Humanizer.Vocabulary.AddUncountable(System.String)
member.summary: Adds an uncountable word to the vocabulary, e.g. "fish". Will be ignored when plurality is changed.
member.param: Word to be added to the list of uncountables.

member.name: M:Humanizer.Vocabulary.AddPlural(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a rule to the vocabulary that does not follow trivial rules for pluralization, e.g. "bus" -> "buses"
member.param: RegEx to be matched, case insensitive, e.g. "(bus)es$"
RegEx replacement e.g. "$1"

member.name: M:Humanizer.Vocabulary.AddSingular(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a rule to the vocabulary that does not follow trivial rules for singularization, e.g. "vertices/indices -> "vertex/index"
member.param: RegEx to be matched, case insensitive, e.g. ""(vert|ind)ices$""
RegEx replacement e.g. "$1ex"

member.name: M:Humanizer.Vocabulary.Pluralize(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Pluralizes the provided input considering irregular words
member.param: Word to be pluralized
Normally you call Pluralize on singular words; but if you're unsure call it with false

member.name: M:Humanizer.Vocabulary.Singularize(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Singularizes the provided input considering irregular words
member.param: Word to be singularized
Normally you call Singularize on plural words; but if you're unsure call it with false
Skip singularizing single words that have an 's' on the end

member.name: M:Humanizer.Vocabulary.LetterS(System.String)
member.summary: If the word is the letter s, singular or plural, return the letter s singular

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Pluralize(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts a singular word to its plural form, handling both regular and irregular pluralizations.
member.param: The word to be pluralized. Can be null.

Indicates whether the input is known to be in singular form. Set to true (default) if you're certain the word is singular. Set to false if the word might already be plural, in which case the method will check and avoid double-pluralization.
member.returns: The plural form of the word, or null if the input was null. Handles irregular plurals (e.g., "person" "people", "child" "children") and regular plurals (e.g., "cat" "cats").
member.remarks: Uses the default vocabulary which includes English pluralization rules and common irregular forms.

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Singularize(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts a plural word to its singular form, handling both regular and irregular singularizations.
member.param: The word to be singularized. Must not be null.

Indicates whether the input is known to be in plural form. Set to true (default) if you're certain the word is plural. Set to false if the word might already be singular, in which case the method will check and avoid incorrect singularization.
When true, skips singularization of simple words that just end in 's'. This helps avoid incorrectly singularizing words like "ross" to "ros".
member.returns: The singular form of the word. Handles irregular singulars (e.g., "people" "person", "children" "child") and regular singulars (e.g., "cats" "cat").
member.remarks: Uses the default vocabulary which includes English singularization rules and common irregular forms.

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Titleize(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to title case by humanizing it first and then applying title casing. Each word in the result will start with an uppercase letter.
member.param: The string to be converted to title case. Must not be null.
member.returns: A humanized string with each word capitalized (title case). If humanization produces an empty string, returns the original input unchanged.
member.remarks: This method first humanizes the input (breaking up PascalCase, underscores, etc.) and then applies title casing.

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Pascalize(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to PascalCase (UpperCamelCase) by capitalizing the first letter of each word and removing spaces, underscores, and dashes.
member.param: The string to be pascalized. Must not be null.
member.returns: A PascalCase version of the input where each word starts with an uppercase letter and spaces, underscores, and dashes are removed.
member.remarks: PascalCase (also known as UpperCamelCase) is commonly used for class names and type names in .NET.

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Camelize(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to camelCase (lowerCamelCase) by capitalizing the first letter of each word except the first word, and removing spaces, underscores, and dashes.
member.param: The string to be camelized. Must not be null.
member.returns: A camelCase version of the input where the first word starts with a lowercase letter, subsequent words start with uppercase letters, and spaces, underscores, and dashes are removed.
member.remarks: camelCase is the same as PascalCase except the first character is lowercase. It's commonly used for variable and method parameter names in .NET.

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Underscore(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to lowercase and separates words with underscores, transforming PascalCase, camelCase, and spaces into underscore_case.
member.param: The string to be underscored. Must not be null.
member.returns: A lowercase string with words separated by underscores instead of spaces, case changes, or dashes.
member.remarks: This transformation is commonly used for database column names, file names, and URL slugs in some conventions.

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Dasherize(System.String)
member.summary: Replaces all underscores in the string with dashes (hyphens).
member.param: The string containing underscores to be replaced with dashes. Must not be null.
member.returns: A string with all underscores replaced by dashes.
member.remarks: This is typically used after calling to convert from underscore_case to dash-case (kebab-case).

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Hyphenate(System.String)
member.summary: Replaces all underscores in the string with hyphens. This is an alias for .
member.param: The string containing underscores to be replaced with hyphens. Must not be null.
member.returns: A string with all underscores replaced by hyphens.
member.remarks: This method is functionally identical to and is provided for API clarity.

member.name: M:Humanizer.InflectorExtensions.Kebaberize(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to kebab-case (lowercase words separated by hyphens), transforming PascalCase, camelCase, spaces, and underscores into hyphenated lowercase text.
member.param: The string to be converted to kebab-case. Must not be null.
member.returns: A lowercase string with words separated by hyphens.
member.remarks: Kebab-case is commonly used for CSS class names, HTML attributes, and URL slugs. This is equivalent to calling followed by .

member.name: T:Humanizer.NumberToTimeSpanExtensions
member.summary: Provides extension methods for converting numeric values to instances, enabling fluent and readable time duration creation (e.g., 5.Seconds(), 3.Hours(), 2.Weeks()).
member.remarks: These extensions make it easy to create TimeSpan values in a more natural, readable way: - Instead of TimeSpan.FromHours(3), you can write 3.Hours() - Instead of TimeSpan.FromMinutes(30), you can write 30.Minutes() - Supports all numeric types: byte, sbyte, short, ushort, int, uint, long, ulong, and double - Weeks are converted to days (1 week = 7 days)

member.name: M:Humanizer.NumberToTimeSpanExtensions.Milliseconds(System.Byte)
member.summary: Creates a representing the specified number of milliseconds.
member.param: The number of milliseconds.

example.code: 500.Milliseconds() => TimeSpan representing 500 milliseconds 1000.Milliseconds() => TimeSpan representing 1 second

member.name: T:Humanizer.RomanNumeralExtensions
member.summary: Contains extension methods for changing a number to Roman representation (ToRoman) and from Roman representation back to the number (FromRoman)

member.name: M:Humanizer.RomanNumeralExtensions.FromRoman(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a Roman numeral string to its integer representation.
member.param: The Roman numeral string to convert (e.g., "XIV", "MCMXC"). Must not be null.
member.returns: The integer value represented by the Roman numeral.
member.exception: Thrown when is null.
Thrown when is empty or contains an invalid Roman numeral format.
member.remarks: Valid Roman numerals use the characters M, D, C, L, X, V, and I (case-insensitive). Supports subtractive notation (e.g., IV = 4, IX = 9, XL = 40, XC = 90, CD = 400, CM = 900). Valid range is 1 to 3999.

member.name: M:Humanizer.RomanNumeralExtensions.FromRoman(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char})
member.summary: Converts a Roman numeral character span to its integer representation.
member.param: The Roman numeral character span to convert. Must not be empty.
member.returns: The integer value represented by the Roman numeral.
member.exception: Thrown when is empty (after trimming) or contains an invalid Roman numeral format.
member.remarks: This is a memory-efficient overload that works with character spans to avoid string allocations. Valid Roman numerals use the characters M, D, C, L, X, V, and I (case-insensitive). Supports subtractive notation (e.g., IV = 4, IX = 9).

member.name: M:Humanizer.RomanNumeralExtensions.ToRoman(System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts an integer to its Roman numeral representation.
member.param: The integer value to convert. Must be between 1 and 3999 inclusive.
member.returns: A string containing the Roman numeral representation of the input value.
member.exception: Thrown when is less than 1 or greater than 3999. Roman numerals are traditionally limited to this range.
member.remarks: Uses standard Roman numeral notation including subtractive notation for 4, 9, 40, 90, 400, and 900. The implementation is optimized for performance and avoids string allocations where possible.

member.name: T:Humanizer.StringDehumanizeExtensions
member.summary: Contains extension methods for dehumanizing strings.

member.name: M:Humanizer.StringDehumanizeExtensions.Dehumanize(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a humanized string back to PascalCase format by removing spaces and capitalizing each word.
member.param: The string to be dehumanized. Must not be null.
member.returns: A PascalCase string with all spaces removed and each word capitalized. If the input is already in PascalCase (contains no spaces), it is returned unchanged.
member.remarks: This method reverses the humanization process by: 1. Splitting the input on spaces 2. Humanizing each word (to handle any edge cases) 3. Pascalizing each word (capitalizing first letter) 4. Removing all spaces This is the inverse operation of .

example.code: "some string".Dehumanize() => "SomeString" "Some String".Dehumanize() => "SomeString" "Some string".Dehumanize() => "SomeString" "SomeStringAndAnotherString".Dehumanize() => "SomeStringAndAnotherString" // Already dehumanized, returned unchanged

member.name: T:Humanizer.StringHumanizeExtensions
member.summary: Contains extension methods for humanizing string values.

member.name: M:Humanizer.StringHumanizeExtensions.Humanize(System.String)
member.summary: Transforms a string into a human-readable format by intelligently handling PascalCase, camelCase, underscored_strings, and dash-separated-strings, converting them into space-separated text with appropriate capitalization.
member.param: The string to be humanized. Must not be null.
member.returns: A humanized version of the input string with spaces inserted between words and appropriate capitalization. Preserves all-uppercase acronyms unchanged.
member.remarks: The method applies several rules in order: - If the entire input is uppercase (an acronym), it returns unchanged - Handles freestanding underscores/dashes (e.g., "some _ string") - Splits on underscores and dashes - Breaks up PascalCase and camelCase text The first letter of the result is always capitalized.

example.code: "PascalCaseInputString".Humanize() => "Pascal case input string" "Underscored_input_String_is_turned_INTO_sentence".Humanize() => "Underscored input String is turned INTO sentence" "dash-separated-string".Humanize() => "Dash separated string" "HTML".Humanize() => "HTML" "camelCaseText".Humanize() => "Camel case text"

member.name: M:Humanizer.StringHumanizeExtensions.Humanize(System.String,Humanizer.LetterCasing)
member.summary: Transforms a string into a human-readable format and applies the specified letter casing.
member.param: The string to be humanized. Must not be null.
The desired letter casing to apply to the humanized result.
member.returns: A humanized version of the input string with the specified casing applied.
member.remarks: This is a convenience method that combines with .

example.code: "PascalCaseInputString".Humanize(LetterCasing.AllCaps) => "PASCAL CASE INPUT STRING" "PascalCaseInputString".Humanize(LetterCasing.LowerCase) => "pascal case input string" "PascalCaseInputString".Humanize(LetterCasing.Title) => "Pascal Case Input String"

member.name: T:Humanizer.TimeSpanHumanizeExtensions
member.summary: Humanizes TimeSpan into human readable form

member.name: M:Humanizer.TimeSpanHumanizeExtensions.Humanize(System.TimeSpan,System.Int32,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,Humanizer.TimeUnit,Humanizer.TimeUnit,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Turns a TimeSpan into a human readable form. E.g. 1 day.
member.param: The maximum number of time units to return. Defaulted is 1 which means the largest unit is returned
Culture to use. If null, current thread's UI culture is used.
The maximum unit of time to output. The default value is . The time units and will give approximations for time spans bigger 30 days by calculating with 365.2425 days a year and 30.4369 days a month.
The minimum unit of time to output.
The separator to use when combining humanized time parts. If null, the default collection formatter for the current culture is used.
Uses words instead of numbers if true. E.g. one day.

member.name: M:Humanizer.TimeSpanHumanizeExtensions.Humanize(System.TimeSpan,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,Humanizer.TimeUnit,Humanizer.TimeUnit,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Turns a TimeSpan into a human readable form. E.g. 1 day.

Controls whether empty time units should be counted towards maximum number of time units. Leading empty time units never count.
Culture to use. If null, current thread's UI culture is used.

The maximum unit of time to output. The default value is . The time units and will give approximations for time spans bigger than 30 days by calculating with 365.2425 days a year and 30.4369 days a month.
The minimum unit of time to output.
The separator to use when combining humanized time parts. If null, the default collection formatter for the current culture is used.
Uses words instead of numbers if true. E.g. one day.

Culture to use. If null, current thread's UI culture is used.

member.name: T:Humanizer.ShowQuantityAs
member.summary: Enumerates the ways of displaying a quantity value when converting a word to a quantity string.

member.name: F:Humanizer.ShowQuantityAs.None
member.summary: Indicates that no quantity will be included in the formatted string.

member.name: F:Humanizer.ShowQuantityAs.Numeric
member.summary: Indicates that the quantity will be included in the output, formatted as its numeric value (e.g. "1").

member.name: F:Humanizer.ShowQuantityAs.Words
member.summary: Incidates that the quantity will be included in the output, formatted as words (e.g. 123 => "one hundred and twenty three").

member.name: T:Humanizer.ToQuantityExtensions
member.summary: Provides extensions for formatting a word as a quantity.

member.name: M:Humanizer.ToQuantityExtensions.ToQuantity(System.String,System.Int64,Humanizer.ShowQuantityAs)
member.summary: Prefixes the provided word with the number and accordingly pluralizes or singularizes the word
member.param: The word to be prefixed
The quantity of the word
How to show the quantity. Numeric by default
member.example: "request".ToQuantity(0) => "0 requests" "request".ToQuantity(1) => "1 request" "request".ToQuantity(2) => "2 requests" "men".ToQuantity(2) => "2 men" "process".ToQuantity(1200, ShowQuantityAs.Words) => "one thousand two hundred processes"

member.name: M:Humanizer.ToQuantityExtensions.ToQuantity(System.String,System.Int64,System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Prefixes the provided word with the number and accordingly pluralizes or singularizes the word
member.param: The word to be prefixed
The quantity of the word
A standard or custom numeric format string.
An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information.
member.example: "request".ToQuantity(0) => "0 requests" "request".ToQuantity(10000, format: "N0") => "10,000 requests" "request".ToQuantity(1, format: "N0") => "1 request"

member.name: M:Humanizer.ToQuantityExtensions.ToQuantity(System.String,System.Double,System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Prefixes the provided word with the number and accordingly pluralizes or singularizes the word
member.param: The word to be prefixed
The quantity of the word
A standard or custom numeric format string.
An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information.
member.example: "request".ToQuantity(0.2) => "0.2 requests" "request".ToQuantity(10.6, format: "N0") => "10.6 requests" "request".ToQuantity(1.0, format: "N0") => "1 request"

member.name: M:Humanizer.ToQuantityExtensions.ToQuantity(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Prefixes the provided word with the number and accordingly pluralizes or singularizes the word
member.param: The word to be prefixed
The quantity of the word
member.example: "request".ToQuantity(0.2) => "0.2 requests"

member.name: T:Humanizer.TruncateExtensions
member.summary: Allow strings to be truncated

member.name: M:Humanizer.TruncateExtensions.Truncate(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Truncates a string to a specified maximum length using the default truncation string ("") and fixed-length truncator.
member.param: The string to be truncated. Can be null.
The maximum length of the result string, including the truncation indicator.
member.returns: The truncated string if its length exceeds , otherwise the original string. Returns null if is null.
member.remarks: The default truncation indicator is "" (ellipsis), and truncation occurs from the right side of the string.

example.code: "This is a long string".Truncate(10) => "This is a" "Short".Truncate(10) => "Short" null.Truncate(10) => null

member.name: M:Humanizer.TruncateExtensions.Truncate(System.String,System.Int32,Humanizer.ITruncator,Humanizer.TruncateFrom)
member.summary: Truncates a string to a specified maximum length using a custom truncator and truncation direction.
member.param: The string to be truncated. Can be null.
The maximum length of the result string, including the truncation indicator.
The implementation to use for truncation logic. Must not be null.
Specifies from which side of the string to truncate. Default is .
member.returns: The truncated string if its length exceeds , otherwise the original string. Returns null if is null.
member.exception: Thrown when is null.

example.code: "This is a long string".Truncate(10, Truncator.FixedLength, TruncateFrom.Left) => "ng string" "This is a long string".Truncate(10, Truncator.FixedNumberOfWords) => "This is"

member.name: M:Humanizer.TruncateExtensions.Truncate(System.String,System.Int32,System.String,Humanizer.TruncateFrom)
member.summary: Truncates a string to a specified maximum length using a custom truncation string and fixed-length truncator.
member.param: The string to be truncated. Can be null.
The maximum length of the result string, including the truncation indicator.
The string to use as the truncation indicator (e.g., "...", "", or any custom string). Can be null or empty.
Specifies from which side of the string to truncate. Default is .
member.returns: The truncated string if its length exceeds , otherwise the original string. Returns null if is null.

example.code: "This is a long string".Truncate(10, "...") => "This is..." "This is a long string".Truncate(15, "--") => "This is a lo--" "This is a long string".Truncate(10, "...", TruncateFrom.Left) => "...string"

member.name: M:Humanizer.TruncateExtensions.Truncate(System.String,System.Int32,System.String,Humanizer.ITruncator,Humanizer.TruncateFrom)
member.summary: Truncates a string to a specified maximum length using a custom truncation string, truncator, and direction.
member.param: The string to be truncated. Can be null.
The maximum length of the result string, including the truncation indicator.
The string to use as the truncation indicator (e.g., "...", "", or any custom string). Can be null or empty.
The implementation to use for truncation logic. Must not be null.
Specifies from which side of the string to truncate. Default is .
member.returns: The truncated string if its length exceeds , otherwise the original string. Returns null if is null.
member.exception: Thrown when is null.
member.remarks: This is the most flexible truncation method, allowing full customization of the truncation behavior.

example.code: "This is a long string".Truncate(10, "...", Truncator.FixedLength, TruncateFrom.Right) => "This is..." "This is a long string".Truncate(10, "", Truncator.FixedNumberOfWords, TruncateFrom.Left) => " string"

member.name: T:Humanizer.TruncateFrom
member.summary: Truncation location for humanizer

member.name: F:Humanizer.TruncateFrom.Left
member.summary: Truncate letters from the left (start) of the string

member.name: F:Humanizer.TruncateFrom.Right
member.summary: Truncate letters from the right (end) of the string

member.name: T:Humanizer.DynamicLengthAndPreserveWordsTruncator
member.summary: Truncate a string to a fixed length while preserving whole words. If the truncation point falls in the middle of a word, that word is dropped entirely and the delimiter is attached. For left-truncation, if no complete word fits in the allowed space, only the delimiter is returned.

member.name: T:Humanizer.DynamicNumberOfCharactersAndPreserveWordsTruncator
member.summary: Truncate a string to a fixed number of letters or digits, preserving whole words by never cutting a word in half. If a complete word (plus the delimiter, if any) cannot fit, then only the delimiter is returned. When truncating from the left, the delimiter is prepended if a complete word can be preserved; otherwise, only the delimiter is returned. The allowed count is computed by counting only letters/digits.

member.name: T:Humanizer.FixedLengthTruncator
member.summary: Truncate a string to a fixed length

member.name: T:Humanizer.FixedNumberOfCharactersTruncator
member.summary: Truncate a string to a fixed number of letters or digits

member.name: T:Humanizer.FixedNumberOfWordsTruncator
member.summary: Truncate a string to a fixed number of words

member.name: T:Humanizer.TupleizeExtensions
member.summary: Convert int to named tuple strings (1 -> 'single', 2-> 'double' etc.). Only values 1-10, 100, and 1000 have specific names. All others will return 'n-tuple'.

member.name: M:Humanizer.TupleizeExtensions.Tupleize(System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts an integer to its corresponding tuple name (e.g., 'single', 'double', 'triple').
member.param: The integer value to convert to a tuple name.
member.returns: A string representing the tuple name: - 1 returns "single" - 2 returns "double" - 3 returns "triple" - 4 returns "quadruple" - 5 returns "quintuple" - 6 returns "sextuple" - 7 returns "septuple" - 8 returns "octuple" - 9 returns "nonuple" - 10 returns "decuple" - 100 returns "centuple" - 1000 returns "milluple" - Any other value returns "{value}-tuple" (e.g., "42-tuple")
member.remarks: Only values 1-10, 100, and 1000 have specific named tuples. All other values return a generic n-tuple format. Negative values and zero will return in the format "{value}-tuple".

member.name: F:Humanizer.WordForm.Abbreviation

member.name: T:Humanizer.WordsToNumberExtension
member.summary: Transform humanized string to number; e.g. one => 1

member.name: M:Humanizer.WordsToNumberExtension.ToNumber(System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts a spelled-out number string to its integer representation.
member.param: The spelled-out number (e.g., "three hundred twenty-one", "forty-two"). Must not be null.
The culture to use for parsing. Different cultures may have different word representations for numbers (e.g., "twenty" in English vs. "vingt" in French).
member.returns: The integer value represented by the words.
member.exception: Thrown when the input contains unrecognized words or cannot be parsed as a number.
Thrown when is null.
member.remarks: This method strictly parses the input and throws an exception if any word is not recognized. For a non-throwing version, use .

member.name: M:Humanizer.WordsToNumberExtension.TryToNumber(System.String,System.Int32@,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Attempts to convert a spelled-out number string to its integer representation without throwing exceptions.
member.param: The spelled-out number (e.g., "forty-two", "one hundred"). Must not be null.
When this method returns, contains the integer value represented by the words if the conversion succeeded, or 0 if the conversion failed.
The culture to use for parsing.
member.returns: true if the conversion was successful; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This is the recommended method for parsing when you're not sure if the input is valid. It does not throw exceptions on invalid input.

member.name: M:Humanizer.WordsToNumberExtension.TryToNumber(System.String,System.Int32@,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.String@)
member.summary: Attempts to convert a spelled-out number string to its integer representation and provides the first unrecognized word if the conversion fails.
member.param: The spelled-out number (e.g., "one thousand one"). Must not be null.
When this method returns, contains the integer value represented by the words if the conversion succeeded, or 0 if the conversion failed.
The culture to use for parsing.
When this method returns false, contains the first unrecognized word found in the input. When this method returns true, this parameter is set to null.
member.returns: true if the conversion was successful; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This overload is useful for debugging or providing detailed error messages to users, as it identifies which specific word caused the parsing failure.
